content.text: In 1931, Kurt Gödel proved one of the most profound results in the history of logic: any consistent formal system capable of expressing basic arithmetic is **incomplete** — there exist true statements it cannot prove.

content.definition: For any consistent, sufficiently powerful formal system F, there exists a sentence G such that: G is true, but F cannot prove G, and F cannot prove ¬G.

content.text: Gödel constructed a sentence that essentially says 'This sentence is not provable in system F.' If F could prove it, F would be inconsistent. If F is consistent, the sentence is true but unprovable.

content.definition: No consistent, sufficiently powerful formal system can prove its own consistency. If F proves 'F is consistent,' then F is actually inconsistent.

content.text: This shattered Hilbert's dream of finding a complete, consistent foundation for all mathematics. Some truths are beyond the reach of any single formal system — a fundamental limit of formal reasoning.

content.title: The Gödel Sentence
premises: G = 'This sentence is not provable in F'
If F proves G, then G is false, so F proves something false (F is unsound)
If F is sound, F cannot prove G
But then G is true! (It really is unprovable)
content.note: The Gödel sentence is true precisely because it cannot be proven — a profound self-referential twist.

content.question: What did Gödel's First Incompleteness Theorem show?
options: Some true statements cannot be proven in any consistent system strong enough for arithmetic
content.explanation: Gödel showed that in any consistent formal system capable of basic arithmetic, there exist true statements that the system cannot prove. This is a fundamental limit, not a flaw.
